intro: Ocimum tomentosum, commonly known as Mexican oregano, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and Central America. It is a member of the Lamiaceae family, characterized by its square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with small, tubular flowers that are usually purple or white. Its leaves are hairy and have a strong, pungent aroma, often used in culinary and medicinal applications. Ocimum tomentosum thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a popular choice for both ornamental and herbal gardens.
